thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: Cruise smackdown: Disney Fantasy vs. Disney Magic
thread.title_full: Cruise smackdown: Disney Fantasy vs. Disney Magic

title: Cruise smackdown: Disney Fantasy vs. Disney Magic
text:
The Disney Cruise Line's newest ship, the Disney Fantasy, arrived in New York on Feb. 28, 2012 after sailing across the Atlantic Ocean from Germany, where it was built. Getty Images Fullscreen The 130,000-ton Disney Fantasy is a sister to the Disney Dream, which debuted in 2011. The two new ships are the Disney Cruise Line's first in more than a decade. Getty Images Fullscreen Built at the Meyer Werft shipyard in Papenburg, Germany, the Disney Fantasy is based year-round in Port Canveral, Fla., sailing seven-night Caribbean and Bahamas itineraries. Getty Images Fullscreen While similar in size to the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy isn't a carbon copy of the earlier ship. Among interior areas that are different on the Fantasy is the atrium lobby, which has an Art Nouveau theme in contrast to the Art Deco decor of the Disney Dream's lobby. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The three-deck-high atrium features a massive crystal chandelier as well as hand-tufted carpets and marble floors. Designed as a central gathering place for passengers, it will offer slightly more public space than its counterpart on the Disney Dream thanks to the elimination of some staff offices. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The atrium lobby's focal point is a cast-bronze statue of Minnie Mouse dressed in vintage 1920s fashion. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the Minnie Mouse statue. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Disney Fantasy's atrium Lobby also is home to the Bon Voyage Bar, where passengers can grab a drink before heading into the nearby Walt Disney Theatre. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Fantasy's atrium lobby also features a number of hand-crafted touches including this intricate mosaic art piece depicting a fairy-tale coach. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy has several shops selling Disney-themed goods including Princess costumes and plush toys. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Disney Fantasy's Royal Court restaurant is similar but not identical to the Princess-themed Royal Palace restaurant found on the Disney Dream. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Royal Court restaurant is one of three main restaurants on the Disney Fantasy. Passengers -- and their waiters -- rotate between the three eateries each night. Gene Sloan Fullscreen An elegant, 10-person circular table sits at the center of the Royal Court. While it's prominently positioned in the manner of a traditional cruise ship Captain's Table, Disney doesn't call it that as the Disney Fantasy's captain won't regularly eat at it. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The walls of the Royal Court are decorated with elaborate mosaics. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The place settings in the Royal Court restaurant feature jacket-shaped napkins. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A hallway on Deck 3 that connects the atrium lobby with two of the ship's main restaurants. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the circular windows that run along the main hallway of Deck 3. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The entrance to Animator's Palate, another one of the three main restaurants on the ship. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like restaurants of the same name on other Disney ships, the Disney Fantasy's Animator's Palate has an animation theme that includes columns shaped like paint brushes and pencils. Gene Sloan Fullscreen As on the Disney Dream, the walls of Animator's Palate on the Disney Fantasy come to life during meals with an interactive show. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy has an adults-only nighttime entertainment area, but with a new theme. The Europe-themed "Europa" area includes an Italy-influenced Piazza, shown here. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Also in Europa is Ooh La La, a champagne bar designed to resemble an elegant French boudoir. The "jewel box" design includes velvet-tufted walls, Victorian furniture and Louis XIV-style chaise lounges. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The bar area of Oh La La. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Europa also is home to an Irish-themed pub called O'Gills (the Disney Dream had a U.K.-style pub). Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up at the bar at O'Gills, which features faux wood beams, ceilings and flooring. Gene Sloan Fullscreen O'Gills has several beers on tap, including a house brand called O'Gills and Murphy's Irish Red. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Europa also is home to the Skyline lounge, where (high-tech) windows look out over a different city every night.The concept first debuted on the Disney Dream. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Dubbed The Tube, the Disney Fantasy's nightclub has a London theme with 1960s-inspired furniture, red English phone booths and what designers describe as an illuminated Union Jack dance floor. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Tube's centrally-located bar is inspired by Big Ben and London's many train stations, and there are nearby seating nooks designed to look like they're part of a subway car. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of The Tube's dance floor. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the subway car-themed seating areas at the Tube. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Among the little details of the Europa entertainment zone are bathrooms lined with mosaics depicting Spanish themes. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Shutters, on Deck 4, is where passengers will find photos taken by ship photographers. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A new space on the Disney Fantasy is dedicated to Shutters Digital, an area where passengers can view photographs taken by ship photographers in digital form. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The interior of Shutters Digital. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A giant picture of Walt Disney marks the entryway to the Walt Disney Theatre, the ship's main showroom. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy also houses a second theater called the Buena Vista. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Buena Vista Theatre shows first-run Disney movies and other films. Like the main Walt Disney Theatre, it is equipped for 3-D shows. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Disney Fantasy's It's a Small World Nursery, on Deck 5, is aimed at children three months to three years old. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The sleeping area in the It's a Small World Nursery. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Aimed at children ages 3 to 7, Disney's Oceaneer Club includes a Toy Story-themed area called Andy's Room with oversized toys. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another view of the Toy Story room in the Oceaneer Club. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another play area in the Oceaneer Club called Monster's Academy has a structure themed around the movie Monsters Inc. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Oceaneer Club also has an interactive, computerized floor game. Gene Sloan Fullscreen An area of the Oceaneer Club called Pixie Hollow where kids can take part in dress-up play and work on craft projects. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Dresses for dress-up play awaiting youngsters in the Pixie Hollow area of the Oceaneer Club. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A view inside the Finding Nemo-themed submarine in the Oceaneer Club. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another children's area called the Oceaneer Lab is aimed at children ages 7 to 10 and includes a craft area, shown here. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Disney film stills and other Disney-themed art line the hallways of the ship. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located atop the ship on Deck 11, Cove Café is an adults-only lounge just off an adults-only outdoor area called Quiet Cove. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Quiet Cove Pool is reserved for adults 18 and older and is home to the Cove Bar, where one can order a drink without getting out of the water. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another view of the Quiet Cove Pool area, which is located on Deck 11. Gene Sloan Fullscreen New on Disney Fantasy is a splash pool area called Satellite Falls that surrounds a satellite fixture at the front of the ship. It features a "rain curtain" of water and is part of an adults-only area that includes new shaded areas for lounging. Gene Sloan Fullscreen As on the Disney Dream, the middle of the Disney Fantasy is home to the adjacent Donald's Pool, foreground, and Mickey's Pool, both of which can be covered during deck-top events. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy also has an AquaDuck "water coaster." It runs 765 feet around the top deck of the ship, propelling riders up, down and off the side of the vessel and back. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Mickey's hand holds up a kiddie water slide that deposits riders near Mickey's Pool. The freshwater pool is two feet deep and is for younger children and their parents. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the clear acrylic tube of the AquaDuck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen New on the Disney Fantasy is a kiddie play area called AquaLab that includes watery games such as a "leaky wall" where kids can try to plug ever-changing leaks with their hands. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another view of the AquaLab watery play area showing the interactive "leaky wall." Gene Sloan Fullscreen The entry area for the ship's AquaDuck ride. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Goofy's Sports Deck, on the back of the ship, includes a basketball court. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like the Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy also has a small miniature golf course. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A watery play area for toddlers on the ship's top deck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like other ships, the Disney Fantasy has (no-extra-charge) soda machines on its pool deck -- a rarity for big ship lines. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A hot tub on the main pool deck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The ship's casual Cabanas buffet is themed to look like a California boardwalk. It's located just off the pool area on Deck 11 and is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Gene Sloan Fullscreen One of the many food stations at the Cabanas cafe. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Meridien Bar is located at the top of the Disney Fantasy in between the ship's two extra-charge, adults-only restaurants, Palo and Remy. Gene Sloan Fullscreen An elevator area on the Disney Fantasy. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Disney Fantasy features more than a dozen "enchanted art" pieces in hallways that periodically come to life in front of passengers with animated scenes. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of one of the enchanted art pieces as it displays an animated scene. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The same enchanted art piece as in the last photo, moments later. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Disney Fantasy also features a Muppets-themed detective game that passengers can play by holding up a coded card to enchanted art pieces. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Muppets' Kermit the Frog makes an appearance in an enchanted art piece for passengers playing the Muppets-themed detective game. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Hidden on the ship is a (faux) miniature door to Pepe the Prawn's that plays a role in the Muppets-themed detective game. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The espresso-serving Vista Cafe is on Deck 4, overlooking the ship's atrium lobby. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Vista Gallery offers Disney-themed paintings and animation stills for sale. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Port Adventures desk, where passengers can book shore excursions. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique, on Deck 5, where children can get makeovers to look like a princess or a pirate. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Princess dresses for sale at the Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique. Princess costumes come complete with wands and shoes. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The D Lounge, on Deck 4, is a casual, family-friendly lounge and nightclub where parents and their children will find daily activities including games, karaoke and dancing. Gene Sloan One of the most notable new features on the revamped Disney Magic is the AquaDunk, a 37-foot-tall body slide that careens over the side of the ship. It begins with a surprise launch when the floor beneath the rider opens like a trapdoor. (Photo: Gene Sloan, USA TODAY)
1 CONNECT 6 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Is newer better when it comes to Disney ships? Readers, we want to hear what you have to say!
In this, the sixth of our new series of Cruise Ship Smackdowns , we're pitting one of Disney Cruise Line's two new vessels, the Disney Fantasy , against one of its original two ships, the Disney Magic .
Click through the photo tours of the two vessels in the carousels above and below, then go the comment area to tell us: Which one would you prefer for a cruise vacation -- and why?
Unveiled in 2012 and 1998, respectively, the Disney Fantasy and Disney Magic each boast all the trappings of a major family resort, from deck-top fun zones with pools and water features to expansive interior children's areas and family-friendly entertainment. Still, as you can see in the photo tours, they are very different ships.
USA TODAY
Experience 'Frozen' fun on Disney's new Norwegian Fjords cruises
Like sister Disney Dream, the Disney Fantasy is significantly larger than the Disney Magic at 130,000 tons vs 83.338 tons. Holding 2,500 passengers at double occupancy, it features one of the most innovative deck-top attractions at sea, the 765-foot-long AquaDuck "water coaster." It's also home to a kiddie water slide, deck-top kiddie play area and several pools, and its insides are loaded with children's play areas, family entertainment and even an adults-only night zone called Europa. The vessel sails year-round to the Caribbean out of Port Canaveral, Fla.
While more than a decade older than the Disney Fantasy, the Disney Magic recently underwent a major makeover that brought such cutting-edge features as the AquaDunk, a 37-foot-tall body slide that careens over the side of the ship, as well as a new outdoor kiddie fun zone called the AquaLab. It also has multiple deck-top pool areas and indoor children's zones that cover almost an entire deck. More intimate than the Disney Fantasy because of its smaller size, the 1,754-passengers-at-double-occupancy Disney Magic sails in Europe as well as the Caribbean.
Originally unveiled in 1998, Disney Cruise Line’s Disney Magic underwent a massive makeover in late 2013 that brought new and improved public areas and completely revamped cabins. Matt Stroshane, photographer Fullscreen At 83,308 tons, the Disney Magic is relatively modest in size compared to some of the latest mega-ships. It holds just 1,754 passengers at double occupancy but, with all berths filled, can accommodate 2,700. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen From the outside, Disney Magic cuts an elegant figure with a sleek design that was inspired by ocean liners of the 1930s. The ship is known for extensive children's areas and (Disney-themed) entertainment that is at a quality level rarely seen in the cruise industry. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The hub of Disney Magic's top deck is its family-friendly Goofy’s Family Pool area. It's flanked by two whirlpools on one side and a stage and dance floor on the other. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Goofy Family Pool area also is home to a giant, 24-foot-wide LED screen that plays current and classic Disney films throughout the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One of the most notable new features on the revamped Disney Magic is the AquaDunk, a 37-foot-tall body slide that careens over the side of the ship. It begins with a surprise launch when the floor beneath the rider opens like a trapdoor. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The top of the Disney Magic is encircled on Deck 10 by a wrap-around sunning area with lounge chairs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located just aft of Disney Magic's two funnels on Deck 9 is a second pool area dedicated to children. Called the AquaLab, it's home to a freshwater pool, water slide and watery play area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The AquaLab features squirting pop jets and other watery features that were added during the makeover of the Disney Magic in 2013. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also added in 2013, the AquaLab's 250-foot-long, spiraling water slide is called Twist n' Spout. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One of many kid-friendly touches on the Disney Magic is the rack of children's life jackets available for use at the AquaLab pool area for no extra charge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located toward the front of the ship is a third pool zone called Quiet Cove that is for adults only. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Quiet Cove has a four-foot-deep main pool and two whirlpools. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Quiet Cove adults pool area has an elegant feel that comes in part from its rows of lovely teak lounge chairs with plush cushions. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen White pool towels are available in wooden cabinets located around the pool decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located at Quiet Cove, Signals is an adults-only outdoor bar. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Quiet Cove area on the Disney Magic also features cushioned deck chairs and solid teak decking. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One deck up from the Disney Magic's pools on Deck 10 is a deck area that wraps around the sides of the ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Teak tables and chairs can be found overlooking the water on Deck 9 near the main Goofy Family Pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just off the AquaLab kiddie pool area is a small quick-serve food outlet called Daisy De-Lites. It offers paninis, salads and fruit during the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The hub of Disney Magic's interior is the Lobby Atrium. It received a major overhaul in 2013 that included the removal of one of two sweeping staircases and the addition of a new chandelier. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The changes to the Disney Magic's Lobby Atrium made more room for events such as Disney character meet-and-greets. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Disney Magic's Lobby Atrium still is home to the ship's iconic Mickey statue. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Designed with Art Deco flourishes, the Disney Magic offers such retro motifs as large circular windows along public corridors. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic’s largest public space, the 977-seat Walt Disney Theatre has unobscured sight lines and state-of-the-art sound and lighting. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just outside the Walt Disney Theatre is Preludes Bar, a semi-circular alcove where passengers gather before shows. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Not far from the Walt Disney Theatre on Deck 4 is a shopping area selling Disney-branded merchandise and other items. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located on Deck 5, the 278-seat Buena Vista Theatre shows Disney animated and action movies throughout the day, many in 3D. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located on Deck 3 between two of Disney Magic's three main restaurants, the distinctly Art Deco Promenade Lounge is open to families with children. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Home to live entertainment daily, the Promenade Lounge has a small stage and dance floor. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The rear corner of the Promenade Lounge houses a small Internet center. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located on Deck 4, Animator’s Palate is one of three “rotational” dining venues where passengers share the same table with the same wait staff each night in a different restaurant. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The second of the three main restaurants on Disney Magic is Carioca's, which serves South American cuisine -- a new concept added during the ship's makeover in 2013. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Designed to appeal as much to adults as to kids, Disney Magic features an adults-only entertainment district called After Hours that is home to three distinct venues for dancing, comedy, music and variety shows. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Filling up more than a third of Deck 3, the After Hours area includes an ocean-inspired nightclub called Fathoms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The bar area at Fathoms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Fathoms nightclub has cozy, backlit seating nooks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Fathoms features adult-only entertainment late into the night. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also part of the adults-only After Hours district on the Disney Magic is Keys, a piano bar and lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Keys offers a low-key nighttime experience with the soft sounds of live piano music and hand-crafted drinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Seating areas in the Keys lounge offer views of the ocean through large circular windows. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also part of the After Hours area on Disney Magic is O'Gill's, an Irish-themed pub and sports bar added during the ship's 2013 makeover. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen O'Gills is a lively nightspot that features live bands nightly, trivia contents and other entertainment. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Passengers can climb into cozy window nooks located along a corridor of the adults-only After Hours area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located on Deck 4, the D Lounge is a nightclub and entertainment area that is open to the entire family. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Revamped during the Disney Magic makeover, the D Lounge features games and activities during the day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Art Deco flourishes on the Disney Magic extend to the elevator banks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Like other Disney ships, Disney Magic has a lovely, teak-lined promenade that wraps all the way around the vessel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic's promenade features traditional teak lounge chairs topped with comfortable cushions. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Elegant wooden benches also can be found along Disney Magic's outdoor promenade. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic's promenade also features areas for shuffleboard. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen In addition to its three main restaurants, Disney Magic has a casual buffet eatery called Cabanas on Deck 9 just outside the AquaLab kiddie pool area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Cabanas was expanded with more indoor and outdoor seating during the Disney Magic's makeover in 2013. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner, Cabanas features multiple food stations in a reconfigured layout. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic also has an extra-charge, adults-only Italian eatery called Palo. Located on Deck 10, it's open for brunch and dinner for a cost of $30 per person. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Cabins on the revamped Disney Magic have been redesigned with new, nautical decor and more usable space, including elevated bed frames that provide more storage room underneath. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen In keeping with Disney Magic's family focus, a large number of cabins such as this Deluxe Family Oceanview categoryroom can hold as many as five passengers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Deluxe Family Oceanview cabins have built-in desk areas with televisions and mini-refrigerators. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic cabins have flexible electrical outlets that can accommodate both U.S.- and European-style plugs. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen In another family-friendly twist, most cabins on Disney Magic have two bathrooms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen In addition to a bathroom with sink and toilet, there is a bathroom with sink and tub/shower. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The combined shower and (small) tub in a Deluxe Family Oceanview cabin bathroom. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Concierge cabins and suites on the Disney Magic come with upgraded Elemis toiletries. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Even the towels in cabin bathrooms on Disney Magic have a Disney motif with the logo of the cruise line worked into the fabric. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Disney Magic cabins have large, built-in wardrobes just opposite of the bathrooms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Built-in wardrobes in Disney Magic cabins feature space for hanging clothes, a safe and life jackets. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also new on the revamped Disney Magic is the It's a Small World Nursery for children ages three months to three years. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The It's a Small World Nursery on the Disney Magic is inspired by the namesake Disney Parks attraction. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The It's a Small World Nursery has cribs for nap time. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The makeover of the Disney Magic brought an entirely revamped Oceaneer Club play zone for children that includes a two-story area themed to the Disney-Pixar movie 'Toy Story' called Andy's Room. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One of the most notable new areas for kids on the Disney Magic is the Marvel's Avengers Academy, part of the Oceaneer Club youth area. It features such props as an Iron Man suit. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also new in the Oceaneer Club for children on the Disney Magic is a Mickey Mouse Club area where kids can create crafts and play games on custom, ear-shaped tables. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen New hand-washing stations were added at the entrance to the Oceaneer Club for use by arriving children. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Even the bathrooms in the Oceaneer Club have a Disney theme with Mickey-shaped mirrors. Sinks are set lower to accommodate kids. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The makeover of the Disney Magic also brought an overhaul of the ship's Oceaneer Lab, a second play area for 3-to-12-year-old children. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Oceaneer Lab on the Disney Magic now has a new pirate theme and is filled with hands-on activities. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A lounge area in the Oceaneer Lab where children can watch movies. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The new Oceaneer Lab on the Disney Magic is filled with stations for creative play. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Another children's zone on Disney Magic is Edge, a designated “tween center” for kids ages 11 to 14 located midship on Deck 2. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Play stations at the Edge tween center. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located at the top of the ship in the “dummy” forward funnel on Deck 11, Vibe is the Disney Magic's club for 14- to 17-year-olds. It features a soda bar, dance floor and a number of teen-oriented activities supervised by the ship’s staff. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The forward portion of Deck 10 is home to Wide World of Sports, a games area with a multi-use volleyball/basketball court. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Wide World of Sports area also has ping-pong tables. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Outdoor foosball tables also are part of the Wide World of Sports area on Deck 10. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just off the Goofy Pool area on Deck 9 is an indoor arcade area called Quarter Master’s. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One of the kid-friendly touches on Disney Magic's pool deck is a bank of machines serving complimentary soft serve ice cream. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Complimentary sodas are available on the Disney Magic's pool deck, a rarity among big ship lines. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Even the guest services desk on the Disney Magic received an update during the ship's 2013 makeover. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Disney Magic's gym is located atop Deck 9 in a prime location overlooking the front of the vessel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen DIsney Magic has self-serve launderettes on several cabin decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Disney Magic was built near Venice, Italy by Fincantieri, the Italian state-owned shipbuilding company that has constructed dozens of major cruise ships in recent years. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The bases of Disney Magic's two “crown topped” funnels are inspired by the triple stacks of the famed, 1930s-era SS Normandie. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The AquaLab kiddie pool area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Nephew's Splash Zone is a protected area of the AquaLab reserved for the smallest toddlers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Another food outlet near the pools on Deck 9 is Pinocchio's Pizzeria. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Elevator banks on Disney Magic have Mickey hands above the doors to indicate the location of the elevator. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Shown here docked in Geiranger, Norway, the Disney Magic features an ocean liner-like black hull, white superstructure and black-topped red funnels. Black and white as well as yellow and red also are the colors of Mickey Mouse. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Another new nightspot on the Disney Magic is Fathoms, a night club inspired by the sea. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A life buoy on one of Disney Magic's top decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY 1 CONNECT 6 TWEET 1 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read //usat.ly/1RCc7wT TOP VIDEOS
